title-group.article-title: The Retail Price Index and the Cost-of-Living Index: Testing for Consistency in Theory and Practice

abstract.p: This paper tests the published section-level price and weight data used in the compilation of the UK retail price index (RPI) for consistency with the theory of the cost-of-living index. We use a non-parametric test of theoretical consistency and bootstrap statistical methods to estimate the probability of consistency.

il is important to note that the standard model of consumers' behaviour is not designed for its literal, descriptive properties but for its analytical properties. It is not necessary to believe that consumers actually do the following, just that their behaviour is consistent with it.

The term 'rational' is used here in a technical sense idiosyncratic to Economics. If preferences are rational in this sense, then it means that they satisfy certain regularity conditions/assumptions: completeness, reflexivity, transitivity and continuity. Conversely, if a consumer's preferences conform to these regularity conditions, then they can be represented by a utility function. See Varian (1978, pp. 111-13).

A utility function is a handy technical device, nothing more. It should not be given any psychological interpretation. The particular utility number it produces from a given bundle of goods is not significant. The only relevant feature is its ordinal character. Whilst the FES is one of the primary sources of data for the section weights for the RPI, note that some section weights are calculated from three years of FES data, and others are calculated from alternative sources when the FES is thought to underestimate expenditure on the relevant commodities. Other weights, such as those for council tax, mortgage interest payments and depreciation, are calculated using models (Baxter, 1998). For these reasons, the quantities that correspond to the published weights are not the same as those that we would recover directly from the FES section expenditures. As a result, because we are interested in testing the published data, we do not use the FES to estimate individual section weights but only total expenditure. See the discussion below.

Given the need to publish the index in a timely manner, the use of certain, otherwise rather desirable, formulae, such as the Törnqvist index or Fisher's index, might be impractical, at least without some mechanism for publishing revisions to the index. However, others, such as those based on budget-share-weighted geometric means of period-to-period price ratios (i.e. those that are exact for Cobb-Douglas utility), would be practicable.
